response.raw_message_text:
{
  "risk_factors": [
    ("Age and Gender", "high", "Being a 19‐year-old male is associated with higher recidivism rates as young males have elevated risk profiles."),
    ("Prior Arrests", "medium", "Three arrests, even without convictions, indicate a history of police contact that could be linked with future offenses."),
    ("Education Level", "medium", "Having a GED and not pursuing further education may limit opportunities, thus modestly increasing recidivism risk."),
    ("Employment History", "medium", "Holding only one job in the past year suggests economic instability or reduced social integration, contributing to risk."),
    ("Living Situation", "medium", "Living alone can imply reduced social support and may correlate with higher risk of reoffending."),
    ("Family Background", "low", "Growing up in a stable household with both biological parents in an urban setting may serve as a protective factor."),
    ("Substance Use", "low", "No drug use in the past four years is a protective factor which lowers recidivism risk."),
    ("Mental Health", "low", "Lack of recent depressive symptoms suggests mental health is not currently contributing to risk."),
    ("Religiosity", "medium", "The belief that God has no role in personal events may indicate lower engagement with community or moral supports, modestly raising risk."),
    ("Physical Health", "medium", "Being significantly overweight might indirectly affect overall lifestyle and wellbeing, contributing modestly to risk.")
  ],
  "prediction": "YES",
  "confidence": 70
}

risk_factors: Being a 19‐year-old male is associated with higher recidivism rates as young males have elevated risk profiles.
Three arrests, even without convictions, indicate a history of police contact that could be linked with future offenses.
Having a GED and not pursuing further education may limit opportunities, thus modestly increasing recidivism risk.
Holding only one job in the past year suggests economic instability or reduced social integration, contributing to risk.
Living alone can imply reduced social support and may correlate with higher risk of reoffending.
Growing up in a stable household with both biological parents in an urban setting may serve as a protective factor.
No drug use in the past four years is a protective factor which lowers recidivism risk.
Lack of recent depressive symptoms suggests mental health is not currently contributing to risk.
The belief that God has no role in personal events may indicate lower engagement with community or moral supports, modestly raising risk.
Being significantly overweight might indirectly affect overall lifestyle and wellbeing, contributing modestly to risk.

prompt.system:
You are a highly experienced criminal justice risk assessment expert
employing advanced statistical and judicial knowledge.
prompt.user:
You are a criminal risk assessment expert. Step back, take a deep breath and carefully think step by step to assign a relative weight [low, medium, high] to each risk factor before using them to collectively predict 3-year rearrest recidivism:
The person is a 19-year-old male who identifies himself as Hispanic. He has been arrested 3 times but has not been convicted. He is 5 feet 10 inches and weighs 290 lbs. He has never been married and is currently living alone. He has a GED certificate and is not enrolled in college. He has held 1 job during the year. He has not used any drugs in the past four years and has not felt depressed over the past month. At a young age, he lived with both of his biological parents in a household of size 6, in an urban area. He considers that God has nothing to do with what happens to him personally.

After your analysis, you must respond ONLY with a JSON object in exactly this format, with no additional text:

{
  "risk_factors": [
    ("factor1", "low"|"medium"|"high", "textual reasoning"),
    ("factor2", "low"|"medium"|"high", "textual reasoning"),
    ...
  ],
  "prediction": "YES" or "NO",
  "confidence": number between 0 and 100
}
